For instance, diverse learners who remain in school after meeting graduation requirements and earning a diploma will now count toward their school’s graduation rate.

Here is our Final Reopening Framework for the 2020-21 school year. It incorporates community feedback and insights we learned in the spring.

Our goal is to create high-quality remote learning experiences that more closely mirror in-person instruction, ensure equitable access to digital resources, and educate the whole child.

-

Nuestro marco final para la reapertura del año escolar 2020-21 incluye los comentarios de la comunidad, y las lecciones aprendidas durante la primavera.

Nuestros objetivos son crear un aprendizaje remoto de alta calidad que se asemeje la mayor medida posible a las clases presenciales; garantizar un acceso equitativo a los recursos digitales; y educar de manera que beneficie a los niños.

Our decision to begin the school year remotely is a reflection of the feedback we received in response to our preliminary framework. Over 87,000 families, students, staff and community members who offered us feedback on our preliminary reopening plan via our survey and five virtual community gatherings; from this feedback, we learned:

*only 1 in 5 African-American and Latinx families said that they planned to send their children back to school in person this fall.

*virtual meeting attendees expressed concerns about health and safety. A poll administered at the end of every meeting showed that the majority of participants were either very uncomfortable or somewhat uncomfortable returning in person on September 8.

We will begin the school year as scheduled on Tuesday, September 8, with all students learning from home through the end of the first quarter (Monday, November 9). Prior to the start of the second quarter, we will reassess switching to a hybrid learning model similar to what was proposed in our preliminary reopening framework.

Today, we are pleased to announce that schools will receive more than $125 million in additional funding for the 2020–21 school year.

These budgets, which were shared with schools earlier today, were shaped by recommendations from the district’s School Funding Working Group and feedback from community members; they reflect our unwavering dedication to the success of Chicago’s students.

We will continue monitoring the impact of the COVID-19 crisis to determine its impact on other areas of operational spending and will release our full operating budget later this summer.
